questions.question_text: A network technician works in a large environment with several thousand users. Due to the needs of the organization, the network manager has asked the technician to design a solution that accommodates the data needs of all the users, while keeping all data on site. Which of the following solutions should the technician implement?

comments.content: Dude, just because you're experienced, doesn't mean you're right! It's SAN. There are so many clues pointing to SAN, and no where did the question say that users need to access files, only store!

discussion.content:
Dear Comptia, your answers are wrong sometimes. 12 years of designing storage solutions and here is my answer...

"... the data needs of all the USERS ..."
NAS = Serves USERS with files, can be accessed by
SAN = Serves SERVERS with block storage. SAN can NOT be accessed from LAN by client devices. It's a separate back-end network between STORAGE and SERVERS.

It really doesn't matter how many USERS, there are Enterprise grade NAS solutions which can easily satisfy thousands of users (eg. from EMC or NetApp).
for less than 20-30 users a redundant NAS solution would be ok, but for thousands of users, it must be a SAN
while keeping data on site = SAN
could easily be. the question does not make it obvious...

comments.content: I think the key here is 'several thousand users' which indicates the need for enterprise-grade/level deployment capabilities which includes availability & redundancy

discussion.content: It could be san or nas. SAN is block based while NAS is file based. NAS is more likely easy to install as SAN may require some hardware changes.
keyword: prevent = key card, if it was "detect" = video camera

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be used to prevent unauthorized employees from entering restricted areas?

discussion.content: For those of you who need to hear this, double check and reread the question as it might trip you up on first glance. Your first thought might be E (12) because that is how many ports and collision domains (not broadcast like the question asks for). However the ports corelate with Collision Domains not Broadcast Domains. Switches give multiple devices a single Broadcast Domain but many Collision Domains. Hubs have 1 broadcast AND collision domain while Routes give each device its own Broadcast Domain.

comments.content: It's an unmanaged switch, that's why you only have one broadcast domain. If the switch was managed, you'd have 12 broadcast domains and 12 collision domains.

discussion.content: B is the right answer because it's unmanaged, so if something comes in it goes out to them all.. which is.. all just one broadcast domain, since it's unmanaged.. so like, 1 and stuff.

Selected Answer: B
Unmanaged switch is just like a HUB...

Selected Answer: B
Unmanaged Switch has 1 broadcast domain

comments.content: You think routers create broadcasts? It's the packet sent by devices that are broadcasts. There's one broadcast domain on a switch because any packet sent through the broadcast address is propagated in all ports.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
why it's not A?? it sais how many bcasts are CREATED? nothing is created. broadcast that comes to a switch is already one. switch does not create bcast!! Or does it ?
yes i definitely read that wrong.
B is right, with the switch being unmanaged it nothing now but an expensive hub.

Correct answer is B - 1 broadcast domain
The switch creates 12 collision domains and 1 broadcast domain.
A switch creates a single broadcast domain, not separate broadcast domains so any answer with 12 broadcast domains is incorrect.

A switch creates separate collision domains for each port, not a single collision domain for the entire switch.

https://blogs.getcertifiedgetahead.com/network-segments-and-domains/#question

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the number of broadcast domain that are created when using an unmanaged 12-port switch?

discussion.content: B is a pre shared key, not certificate, C is a access portal for username and password, narrowed down to A and D, gives you a 50/50 chance if you don't know A, but it's D.

questions.question_text: A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) has decided to implement a secure and user-friendly way to connect to the corporate wireless network. Each workstation will be authenticated individually using a unique certificate that will be deployed to the workstation by the organization's certificate authority. Which of the following authentication methods would meet this requirement?

choices.A: The Faraday cage is creating interference within the bookstore.
choices.B: The Faraday cage prevents access by redirecting signals.
choices.C: The Faraday cage is creating latency on the cellular network.
choices.D: The Faraday cage is creating attenuation of the cellular network.

questions.question_text: A bookstore uses a Faraday cage to comply with credit card regulations. Customers report that their cellular phones have no signal when they are in the bookstore. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

discussion.content: A faraday cage? Wheres this mentioned in the exam objectives?
Looks like it's D, attenuation.
I thought it D, how can it be B?
To be honest, this is more a question for Azure exam as Faraday cages are present everywhere when dealing with databses in cloud. Lucky me I`ve done that and got the connection.
I think the given answer could be correct, Faraday cage can intercept signals and redirects them to ground.

Seems like it's D.
A faraday cage doesn't redirect signal, it just cancels it out.
"When electromagnetic radiation - such as a phone signal - hits the outside of a Faraday cage, it causes electrons in the metal to move and create an electromagnetic field that exactly opposes and cancels out that wavelength of radiation."
"Faraday cages can attenuate the frequency of cell phones."

It seems like it could be either or. It redirects the signal and causes attenuation. Assuming that the cell phone is not inside of the cage (which the signal is redirected away from) The cage could be causing attenuation on the outside of the cage causing the signal issue. Honestly i feel like its just a guess at this point.
I would rule out attenuation because the question states the customers have no signal at all. We can also eliminate latency and interference, leaving B the signal is being redirected or blocked.

A Faraday cage or Faraday shield is an enclosure used to block electromagnetic fields.
Firts line on : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_cage

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_cage

Word attenuation on the page: 6
Word redirect on the page: 0
The reception or transmission of radio waves, a form of electromagnetic radiation, to or from an antenna within a Faraday cage is heavily attenuated or blocked by the cage
